case_name: Proprietors of Paikpara Estate v. State of Orissa

facts.text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated March 27, 1958, of the Orissa High Court in O.J.C. No. 191 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated March 27, 1958, of the Orissa, High Court in O. J.C. No. 191 of 1956.

facts.text: The appellants were the proprietors of Paikpara Estate in Puri district bearing Touzi Nos. 268, 269 and 270.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who were petitioners in the High Court were the proprietors of an Estate, known as Paikpara Estate, in the district of Puri, bearing Touzi Nos. 268, 269 and 270.

facts.text: The Paikpara Estate vested in the State of Orissa by virtue of a notification issued under s. 3 of the Act on August 23, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Paikpara Estate vested in the State of Orissa by virtue of a numberification issued under s. 3 of the Act, on August 23, 1953.

facts.text: Interests of tenure-holders and sub-proprietors within the Paikpara Estate have not yet been taken over under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the interests of tenure- holders and sub-proprietors within the said estate have number yet been taken over under the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Occupancy holdings under the tenure-holders were purchased by the proprietors long ago, making proprietors occupancy raiyats.

anchor.surface_text: Under the tenure-holders aforesaid, there were some occupancy holdings which Lad been purchased by the proprietors, the appellants in this Court, long ago. Thus the proprietors by virtue of their purchase became occupancy raiyats

facts.text: Interests as occupancy raiyats in respect of purchased holdings recorded in last Settlement Khatians.

anchor.surface_text: It is also companymon ground that in the last Settlement Khatians their interests as occupancy raiyat8 in respect of the holdings purchased by them have been recorded.

facts.text: Buildings on occupancy holdings used as Katcheri houses by proprietors for estate administration.

anchor.surface_text: On the lands of the occupancy holdings, there were several buildings which were used as Katcheri houses by the proprietors, for the administration of their estate.

facts.text: In January 1954, State Officials took possession of buildings on raiyati land according to petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: In January 1954, according to the petitioners in the High Court, the State Officials took illegal possession of those buildings situate on the raiyati land, as aforesaid.

facts.text: Appellants applied to Collector of Puri for vacant possession of lands and buildings.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereupon made an application to the Collector of Puri for vacant possession of the lands and the buildings, described in the petition, on the allegation that those lands together with the buildings, purchased from tenants with rights of occupancy

facts.text: Part of the house let out to Postal Department; Anchal Adhikari instructed not to pay rent to proprietors.

anchor.surface_text: Part of the said house had been let out to the Postal Department. The Anchal Adhikari of that area wrote to the Postmaster, and Superintendent of Post Offices, number to pay rent to the proprietors.

facts.text: Postal Department vacated portion, which went into occupation of State Government.

anchor.surface_text: The Postal Department, therefore, vacated that portion of the building in their occupation, which has gone into the occupation of the State Government.

facts.text: Dhangola portion let out for storing paddy to third party, taken possession by Naib Tehsildar.

anchor.surface_text: Another portion of the property, which was used as dhangola was let out for storing paddy, to a third party. That dhangola was also taken illegal possession of by the Naib Tehsildar of the place.

facts.text: Collector of Puri held occupancy holding situated within tenure within geographical limits of estate vested in Government, dated November 20, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Collector of Puri did number companycede the demand of the proprietors, and held that the occupancy holding is situated within the tenure held under the proprietors and lay within the geographical limits

facts.text: Proprietors moved High Court under Art. 226 against Collector's order.

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved by the aforesaid order of the Collector, dated November 20, 1956, the proprietors moved the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution for relief against what was alleged to be illegal interference

facts.text: High Court dismissed claim relying on K.C. Gajapati Narayan Deo v. State of Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the proprietors claim chiefly on the ground that the question raised by the petition before the High Court was practically companycluded by the observations of the Supreme Court

facts.text: Appellants purchased raiyati lands with buildings thereon.

anchor.surface_text: They also appear to have purchased the properties in question companyprising raiyati lands with certain buildings thereon from the raiyat.

facts.text: Lands with buildings geographically within estate but not part of estate; held as raiyats not proprietors.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, the position in law is that though these lands with the buildings are situate geographically within the ambit of the appellants estate, they are number part of the estate. In other words, the appellants hold those properties

facts.text: Courts below confused position as ex-proprietors with position as raiyats.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Courts below have number kept clearly in view this distinction. The Collector, in the first instance, and the High Court in the proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution, appear to have fallen into the error

facts.text: High Court concluded buildings vested based on use for administration, not whether part of estate.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has drawn the companyclusion from the decision of this Court in K. C. Gajapati Narayan Deo v. The State of Orissa,  1  and has observed that whether the buildings in question vested in the Government

facts.text: Appellants' raiyati interests not affected by abolition; State illegally took possession.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, it must be held that the appellants raiyati interests in the lands and in the buildings standing on those lands have number been affected by the abolition of his interest as proprietors, and that the State authorities had-illegally taken possession of those.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 30, 1962 by SINHA, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. April 30. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA, C. J.-This appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Orissa

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Orissa raises the question of the interpretation of certain provisions of The Orissa Estates Abolition Act

facts.text: Respondents are State of Orissa and its officials.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are the State of Orissa and its officials.

The Paikpara Estate vested in the State of Orissa by virtue of a notification issued under s. 3 of the Act, on August 23, 1953.

concepts.interpretation: Vesting under s.3 does not extend to raiyati interests acquired by proprietors, even if geographically within the estate.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: s aforesaid, it must be held that the appellants raiyati interests in the lands and in the buildings standing on those lands have number been affected

concepts.unlisted_description: Notification for vesting of estate in the State

anchor.surface_text: Estate has been defined in cl. g of s. 2 of the Act as follows estate includes a part of an estate and means any land held by or vested in an Inter- mediary and included under one entry in any revenue roll or any of the general registers of revenue-paying lands and revenue-free lands, prepared and maintained under the law relating to land revenue for the time being in force or under any rule, order, custom or usage having the force of law, and includes revenue-free lands not entered in any register or revenue-roll and all classes of tenures or under-tenures and any jagir, inam or muafi or other similar grant

concepts.interpretation: Estate includes interests of intermediaries between State and raiyat, but excludes raiyati holdings.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: me that buildings, lying within the ambit of an estate and used primarily for management or administration of the estate, would vest in the Government

anchor.surface_text: Intermediary with reference to any estate means a proprietor, sub-proprietor, landlord, landholder, malguzar, thikadar, gaontia, tenure-holder, undertenure-holder, and includes an inamdar a jagirdar, Zamindar, Ilaquadar, Khorgoshdar, Parganadar, Sarbaraka and Maufidar including the Ruler of an Indian State merged with the State of Orissa and all other holders or owners of interest in land between the raiyat and the State

concepts.interpretation: Intermediaries are all persons holding interests between raiyat and State; Act abolishes them.

anchor.surface_text: The interest of a raiyat is designated by the word holding and is defined by the Orissa Tenancy Act (Bihar and Orissa Act II of 1913), as follows . holding means a parcel or parcels of land held by a raiyat and forming the subject of a separate tenancy.

concepts.interpretation: Raiyati holding is distinct from estate or tenure interests.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: by transfer or by operation of law, might at the same time occupy different status in relation to land. He maybe in respect of a particular area, whi

Under cl (a) of s. 5, the entire estate, including all kinds of lands described in meticulous details, and other non-raiyati lands vest absolutely in the State Government.

concepts.interpretation: Vesting affects proprietary and intermediary interests, not raiyati lands.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: rely ancillary to the acquisition of an estate and forms an integral part of the abolition scheme. Such acquisition would companye within article 31

concepts.interpretation: Katcheri buildings comprised in the estate vest, but not those on raiyati holdings.
concepts.unlisted_description: Definition excluding administrative buildings in estate

anchor.surface_text: This appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Orissa raises the question of the interpretation of certain provisions of The Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951 (Orissa Act 1 of 1952) which hereinafter will be referred to as the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Intended to abolish all intermediaries and establish direct relationship between State and raiyats.

issues.text: Whether the occupancy raiyati holdings purchased by the proprietors, including buildings thereon used as Katcheri houses, vested in the State under s. 3 of the Orissa Estates Abolition Act upon notification

anchor.surface_text: The Paikpara Estate vested in the State of Orissa by virtue of a notification issued under s. 3 of the Act, on August 23, 1953.

issues.text: Whether the vesting of buildings used as office or Katcheri for estate administration depends on their purpose of use rather than whether they are comprised in the estate or on raiyati holdings
Whether the observations in K. C. Gajapati Narayan Deo v. The State of Orissa regarding vesting of administrative buildings apply to buildings on raiyati holdings

issues.text: Whether raiyati interests geographically within an estate but held directly by proprietors as raiyats form part of the estate that vests in the State under the Act

anchor.surface_text: Estate has been defined in cl. g of s. 2 of the Act as follows estate includes a part of an estate and means any land held by or vested in an Inter- mediary and included under one entry in any revenue roll or any of the general registers of revenue-paying lands and revenue-free lands, prepared and maintained under the law relating to land revenue for the time being in force or under any rule, order, custom or usage having the force of law, and includes revenue-free lands not entered in any register or revenue-roll and all classes of tenures or under-tenures and any jagir, inam or muafi or other similar grant

issues.text: Whether rents from raiyati holdings are included in gross assets for compensation under s. 26 without vesting of raiyati interests in the State

arguments.court_reasoning: Homestead definition refers to buildings comprised in the estate; disputed buildings on raiyati land not part of estate

arguments.claim: Estate includes interests of all intermediaries between State and raiyat; Act abolishes intermediaries to establish direct State-raiyat relationship

anchor.surface_text: Reading the two definitions together, the position in law is that estate includes the interest, by whatever name called, of all persons, who hold some right in land between the State at the apex and the raiyat at the base.

arguments.claim: Appellants hold disputed lands and buildings not as proprietors but as raiyats, even if geographically within estate

anchor.surface_text: They also appear to have purchased the properties in question comprising raiyati lands with certain buildings thereon from the raiyat. Hence, the position in law is that though these lands with the buildings are situate geographically within the ambit of the appellants estate, they are not part of the estate.

arguments.claim: Courts below erred by confusing petitioners' position as ex-proprietors with position as raiyats

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Courts below have not kept clearly in view this distinction. The Collector, in the first instance, and the High Court in the proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution, appear to have fallen into the error

arguments.claim: Gajapati observations apply to buildings comprised in estate used for administration, not to those on raiyati holdings

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has drawn the conclusion from the decision of this Court in K. C. Gajapati Narayan Deo v. The State of Orissa, and has observed that whether the buildings in question vested in the Government, on the vesting of the estate under s. 3 of the Act, world depend number upon whether it formed part of the estate acquired by the Government but on the, purpose for which the buildings wore used by the proprietors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Raiyati interests excluded from definition of estate and intermediary; vesting under s.3 and s.5 does not affect holdings recorded as occupancy raiyati

holdings.text: though these lands with the buildings are situate geographically within the ambit of the appellants estate, they are not part of the estate. In other words, the appellants hold those properties with the buildings not as proprietors as such, but as raiyats

anchor.surface_text: Hence, the position in law is that though these lands with the buildings are situate geographically within the ambit of the appellants estate, they are number part of the estate. In other words, the appellants hold those properties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purchased raiyati lands held separately as raiyats under tenure-holders; distinct from proprietary estate per s.2(g) definition

holdings.text: this conclusion drawn by the High Court from the decision of this Court is not well-founded in law

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has drawn the conclusion from the decision of this Court in K. C. Gajapati Narayan Deo v. The State of Orissa,  1  and has observed that whether the buildings in question vested in the Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior case observations apply only to buildings on proprietary lands, not raiyati holdings; distinguished on facts and statutory scope

holdings.text: the second category in the definition of homestead, which has not been permitted to the outgoing Intermediary has reference to any building comprised in such estate. It has no reference to any building standing on raiyati holding or a portion thereof
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(i) homestead exclusion for kutchery buildings limited to those comprised in estate; vesting turns on inclusion in estate, not use

holdings.text: the rent payable by the appellants as raiyats in respect of the disputed lands would form part of the assets which have to be included in the gross assets in determining compensation. But that does not mean that the interests of raiyats also have become vested in the State
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.26 includes raiyati rents in gross assets for compensation to intermediaries without vesting raiyati interests themselves

holdings.text: estate includes the interest, by whatever name called, of all persons, who hold some right in land between the State at the apex and the raiyat at the base. That is to say, the Act is intended to abolish all Intermediaries and rentreceivers and to establish direct relationship between the State, in which all such interests vest, after abolition under the Act, and the tillers of the soil

anchor.surface_text: Reading the two definitions together, the position in law is that estate includes the interest, by whatever name called, of all persons, who hold some right in land between the State at the apex and the raiyat at the base.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(g) and s.2(h) definitions limit estates to intermediary interests between State and raiyat; Act abolishes only those

holdings.text: Under cl (a) of s. 5, the entire estate, including all kinds of lands described in meticulous details, and other non-raiyati lands vest absolutely in the State Government

anchor.surface_text: This becomes further clear with reference to the provisions of s. 5, which lays down the consequences of vesting of an estate in the State. holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5 consequences of vesting confirm exclusion of raiyati lands from absolute vesting
